author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Miss Marple is taking over the world: there is no point trying to resist
text:
Journal business editor Graeme Whitfield comes over a bit funny as duelling version of Miss Marple get him pondering the future Shares Get business news by email Joan Hickson who played Miss Marple 
As capitalism hurtles towards disaster/a bright new dawn (delete as appropriate), the strange affair of the Duelling Marples may come to be seen as something of a tipping point. 
I came across this odd phenomenon as I sat on the sofa flicking through the TV channels, pondering on how it is harder to find something to watch when you have hundreds of choices than it was when we just had four. 
Switching onto ITV3, I came across a Miss Marple dramatisation starring Julia Mackenzie. 
“Get this [rude word] off my telly,” cried the current Mrs Whitters, a phrase she is starting to overuse. “The only Marple I want to see is Joan Hickson.” 
We reminisced for a moment about Sunday nights watching quaint BBC period mysteries, so imagine our surprise when we clicked onto a TV channel called Really (really?) and there was the very Hickson we’d been talking about. 
Our pleasure at finding a superior Marple was somewhat diminished by the realisation that TV was evolving to a state where it had achieve simultaneous Marple. No longer was there a need to offer choice to the public: all we get is slightly different iterations of the same Agatha Christie crimesolving geriatric. 
For a moment we wondered what we could do to stop the Marplisation of popular culture. But there is little point in trying to halt progress. 
It seems likely that, before long, all that terrestrial TV will offer us is a choice between differently aged actresses solving gruesome murders simply by being a sly old fox. TV and film companies will base their entire new output on 12 novels written in the 1930s and ‘40s, while young and male actors will have to make do with bit parts as vicars and gamekeepers. 
Some may bemoan this narrowing of our shared culture, but there is something reassuring about a Marpled future. Instead of the horrors of the daily news, reality TV and England football performances, each night in front of gogglebox will see a murder in the Cotswolds revealed, investigated by an antidilvian amateur slueth and solved within the space of two hours. 
No longer will we worry about Brexit, terrorism or Corbynistas. The only choice we will have to make is between Geraldine McEwan, Margaret Rutherford or Angela Lansbury as our ubiquitous crime-solving old fogy. 
I know some of you will say we should resist and fight until the powers-that-be give us Poirot on every channel. But that way madness lies. Graeme Whitfield is business editor of The Journal
